quoteFirst: All the torpedo tubes of the section were not empty, however, for Lieut. (jg) I. M. Kovar, in 137, at
quoteLast: , picked up an enemy formation at the southern end of the strait and attacked. He had no way of knowing it, but this was Admiral Shima’s second section, coming up to the relief of Admiral Nishimura’s van that had already entered the strait, and indeed had at that very moment been shattered by a vicious American destroyer-torpedo attack.
title: The Mosquito Fleet
author: Keating, Bern, 1915-2004

quoteFirst: It was impossible to obtain accurate information, which made the situation worse. The remainder of the night was spent in trying to collect wounded, improve our original position, and clear the battlefield. At
quoteLast: on the 9th we were relieved by the 10th Liverpool Scottish and proceeded, sorely stricken and almost unmanned by the terrific strain of the recent fighting and the shambles around us, to bivouac south-west of Carnoy.
title: The Fourth Battalion, The King's Own (Royal Lancaster Regiment) and the Great War
author: Wadham, W. F. A. (Walter F. A.); Crossley, J.

quoteFirst: Some said that the Oxfords were wiped out; others that they had captured the trench. Two men were sent forward to reconnoitre, and came back to report that the position was critical. It was now
quoteLast: ; the day was coming and the enemy barrage was growing more intense. Captain Aldworth at once ordered the two Companies to go forward to the assistance of the Oxfords.
title: The War Service of the 1/4 Royal Berkshire Regiment (T. F.)
author: Cruttwell, C. R. M. F. (Charles Robert Mowbray Fraser), 1887-1941

quoteFirst: It was his one whole and sole desire. Hadn’t he had this desire for months past? Hadn’t it been his one dream since
quoteLast: precisely one windy March afternoon? He’d follow hot afoot fast enough. The whole question was, Would she come the merest fraction of a step towards him? Would she even pause to await his coming? Or would he come to the end of the pathway to find that she had eluded him,--a locked gate the end of his quest? And there must be no stumbling, no clumsy blundering on that pathway. Despite his desire for swiftness, he must walk warily.
title: The wiser folly
author: LM (Leslie Moore), 1888-1978

quoteFirst: "If Jack or you had to die in a quarter of an hour's time, that is to say at
quoteLast: in horrible agony, which would you choose?" she asked.
title: Dodo Wonders--
author: Benson, E. F. (Edward Frederic), 1867-1940

quoteFirst: Just at daybreak,
quoteLast: , on the 4th of July, we started off on what proved to be the hardest day’s work we had ever accomplished. We struck out at once across the broad snow-field to the second rock rib on the right, which seemed to lead up to the only line of rocks above.
title: Across Asia on a bicycle
author: Allen, Thomas Gaskell, 1868-1955; Sachtleben, William Lewis, 1866-1953

quoteFirst: “Saw a glare to the eastward, looking like a ship on fire, altered course at
quoteLast: to E.N.E. and ran down at full speed, twelve knots. Discovered the glare to be the whaleship _Eliza Adams_ of New Bedford trying out a whale. Resumed course immediately, S.80.W.

quoteFirst: Then the vision was hidden by a scarlet circle, and a voice said, "Mr H. has got it." Through the red mist of the scarlet circle I looked at my watch (the movement to do so had begun in my mind before I was hit); it was spattered with blood; the hands showed
quoteLast: . The voice which had spoken before said, "Mr H. is killed."

quoteLast: the big bell clanged out a warning, dictionaries were shut, exercise-books handed in, pencil-boxes replaced in desks, and the class filed downstairs to the big schoolroom.
